title: The Unlikely Rise of Carl Nassib, the NFL’s First Openly Gay Player
sub_head: He didn’t start in high school. He was a college walk-on. He became a valuable NFL player. Then he became the first active player to come out as gay in America’s most popular sports league.
body:
Before Carl Nassib could become an icon as the first active NFL player to come out as gay, he had to become an NFL player. For a long time, nobody except Nassib believed that was plausible.
Nassib never started a game in high school. He was a skinny walk-on at Penn State who didn’t make his first start until he was a senior. Yet he set the college football world on fire, became a valuable NFL player—and then on Monday became a historic figure in American sports.
Nassib, a defensive end for the Las Vegas Raiders, became the first NFL player to come out as gay while playing in the league. It was a monumental step in the country’s most popular sport during a time when male athletes at the highest levels of sports coming out as gay remains a rarity.
“I’ve been meaning to do this for a while now,” he said in an Instagram video, “but I finally feel comfortable enough to get it off my chest.”
The revelation drew widespread praise. Players, activists and NFL commissioner Roger Goodell said they were proud of his decision to go public and his courage to become a first. Michael Sam, a 2014 seventh-round draft pick by the St. Louis Rams, had come out as gay but never played a regular-season game. Other players have come out after their careers were over.
